document.docAuthor: Liu, Xingyue, Aspöck, Horst, Yang, Ding & Aspöck, Ulrike
document.docTitle: Amurinocellia sinica Liu, H. Aspock & U. Aspock, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Discovery of Amurinocellia H. Aspöck & U. Aspöck (Raphidioptera: Inocelliidae) in China, with description of two new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Discovery of Amurinocellia H. Aspöck & U. Aspöck (Raphidioptera: Inocelliidae) in China, with description of two new species

heading.emphasis:
Amurinocellia sinica Liu, H. Aspöck & U. Aspöck
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Eidonomically this species is characterized by the yellowish antennae and by a series of yellowish stripes on the meso- and metanota as well as the terga of the pregenital segments. The male ninth gonocoxites roundly produced on posterodorsal corners, with the pseudostyli (gonapophyses 9 ) obliquely directed dorsad.
Description. Male. Body length 10.5 mm; forewing length 8.0–8.5 mm, hindwing length 7.0–7.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female. Body length with ovipositor 15.0 mm, body length without ovipositor 11.0 mm; forewing length 10.0 mm, hindwing length 8.5 mm.

Seventh sternite (
Figs. 13–14
) in lateral view subtrapezoidal with posteroventral corner rounded, in ventral view posterior margin with distinct incision, forming a pair of obtuse processes. Eighth tergite (
Figs. 13–14
) strongly expanded ventrad, nearly enveloping ventral portion of eighth abdominal segment, with posteroventral corners slightly produced into a pair of obtuse processes. Subgenital plate absent. Ectoproct (
Fig. 13
) in lateral view subquadrate, slightly narrowed toward apex. Atrium bursae (
Fig. 15
) rounded, slightly pointed anteriorly; sacculus bursae with apex bulbiformed; receptaculum seminis short, with a pair of Material examined. Holotype ♂ [preserved in alcohol], CHINA : Henan Province, Neixiang County, Baotianman,
33 ° 25 'N
,

,

, Weihai Li ( CAU ). Paratypes

, Yusi Cui ( CAU ).

Amurinocellia sinica

Paramere (gocoxites-gonapophyses-gonostyli complex 10), dorsal view; 12. Hypandrium internum; 13. Female genital segments, lateral view; 14. Same, ventral view; 15. Bursa copulatrix, lateral view. T7: seventh tergite; T8: eighth tergite; T9: ninth tergite; S7: seventh sternite; S8: eighth sternite; S9: ninth sternite; gx9: ninth gonocoxite; e: ectoproct; o: ovipositor; ep: endophallus; p: paramere (gocoxites-gonapophyses-gonostyli complex 10); ps: pseudostylus (gonapophysis 9); g: gonarcus (fused gonocoxites 11); ab: atrium bursae; sb: sacculus bursae; gr: glandula receptaculi; r: receptaculum seminis.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology . The specific epithet ‘
sinica
’ (adjective, feminine) refers to the geographic distribution; possibly the new species is endemic to China .

Remarks. At first glance the new species differs from
A. calida
by the male ninth gonocoxites with the posterodorsal corners roundly prominent, the gonapophyses 9 obliquely directed dorsad, the presence of a pair of bristle tufts on the anteroventral portions of the male ninth gonocoxites, and essentially by the gonocoxitesgonapophyses-gonostyli complex 10 with the proximal portion strongly expanded ventrad, and the female seventh sternite with a pair of obtuse posterior processes. In the holotype of
A. calida
, the male ninth gonocoxite has the posterodorsal corner produced into a triangular lobe, however after having studied additional material of this species (H.
Aspöck et al . 1991
), considerable variation of the apex of the gonocoxites 9 was found: in all these specimens the apex is more or less rounded and not triangular as in the holotype . Another discrepancy concerns the pseudostyli (gonapophyses 9 ) appearing horizontally directed, and without tuft on its anteroventral portion. In the additional materials mentioned above the gonapophyses 9 rather resemble those of
A. sinica
, this might reflect true variability or just an effect of position or swelling by maceration. The most stable character seems to be the proximal portion of the parameres (gonocoxitegonapophyses-gonostyli complex 10 ) which is not expanded ventrad, in the holotype of
A. calida
, and in the additional specimens studied. The posterior incision of the female seventh sternite is V-shaped, forming a pair of triangular posterior processes.
